name: Tribunales
excerpt: Tribunales was built as a result of González Videla’s Plan Serena.
detail_description: Tribunales was built as a result of González Videla’s Plan Serena.

name: Mercado La Recova
excerpt: La Serena's most vibrant market offers a jumble of dried fruits, rain sticks and artisan jewelry, plus a wide range of Andean wool clothing and crafts. It…
detail_description: La Serena's most vibrant market offers a jumble of dried fruits, rain sticks and artisan jewelry, plus a wide range of Andean wool clothing and crafts. It's a handy spot for gift ideas.

name: Iglesia Catedral
excerpt: The handsome neoclassical Iglesia Catedral dates from 1844; it also has a sobering museum of religious art.
detail_description: The handsome neoclassical Iglesia Catedral dates from 1844; it also has a sobering museum of religious art.

name: Iglesia San Francisco
excerpt: The granddaddy of all La Serena's churches is a colonial marvel, two blocks southeast of the plaza and built in the early 1600s. It's a stone construction…
detail_description: The granddaddy of all La Serena's churches is a colonial marvel, two blocks southeast of the plaza and built in the early 1600s. It's a stone construction, with a tower and fancy baroque facade.

name: Patio Colonial
excerpt: Tucked off Balmaceda, this small, picturesque lane is dotted with shops and eateries. The patio in back feels like a secret getaway from the city-center…
detail_description: Tucked off Balmaceda, this small, picturesque lane is dotted with shops and eateries. The patio in back feels like a secret getaway from the city-center bustle, and makes a fine spot for an alfresco coffee or snack.

name: Iglesia Santo Domingo
excerpt: The dainty-looking bell tower of Iglesia Santo Domingo looks as though it should have a twirling ballerina inside. The tower is a later addition, only a…
detail_description: The dainty-looking bell tower of Iglesia Santo Domingo looks as though it should have a twirling ballerina inside. The tower is a later addition, only a century old, though the attractive limestone church dates to 1755.

name: Jardín del Corazón
excerpt: With its trickling brooks, drifting swans and neatly manicured rock gardens, this Japanese garden makes an idyllic escape from the city bustle. Don't miss…
detail_description: With its trickling brooks, drifting swans and neatly manicured rock gardens, this Japanese garden makes an idyllic escape from the city bustle. Don't miss the greenhouse collection of adorable bonsai trees in diminutive forms of ciruela (cherry), higuera (fig) and ficus trees.

name: Plaza de Armas
excerpt: The heart of the colonial center is the palm-filled Plaza de Armas. The picturesque square makes a fine place for a stroll with a bit of people-watching…
detail_description: The heart of the colonial center is the palm-filled Plaza de Armas. The picturesque square makes a fine place for a stroll with a bit of people-watching. It's also framed by some of the city's most photogenic buildings.

name: Museo Arqueológico
excerpt: Inside a crescent-shaped building with a leafy patio, this museum makes an ambitious attempt to corral Chile's pre-Columbian past. Its highlights include…
detail_description: Inside a crescent-shaped building with a leafy patio, this museum makes an ambitious attempt to corral Chile's pre-Columbian past. Its highlights include an Atacameña mummy, a hefty 2.5m-high moai (large anthropomorphic statue) from Easter Island and interesting Diaguita artifacts such as a dinghy made from sea-lion hide.

name: Iglesia La Merced
excerpt: One of the town's historic churches.
detail_description: One of the town's historic churches.

name: Municipalidad
excerpt: Pop your head inside to check out photos of the city's past.
detail_description: Pop your head inside to check out photos of the city's past.

name: Museo Histórico Casa Gabriel González Videla
excerpt: Although richly stocked with general historical artifacts, this two-story museum in an 18th-century mansion concentrates on one of La Serena's best-known …
detail_description:
Although richly stocked with general historical artifacts, this two-story museum in an 18th-century mansion concentrates on one of La Serena's best-known (and most controversial) sons. González Videla was Chile's president from 1946 to 1952. Ever the cunning politician, he took power with communist support but then promptly outlawed the party, driving poet Pablo Neruda out of the Senate and into exile. Controversy aside, González Videla was the world's first head of state to visit Antarctica (in 1948).
Head upstairs for a look at curios from the past, including 19th-century drawings of La Serena, elaborate saddles and leather boxes, and some rather dangerous-looking drinking horns.
